Photography Society's 'Inside Outside' exhibition

01/04/2022

Lawrence Mason reviews Photography Society's first exhibition since the beginning of the pandemic.

Image by Chen Manqing

By Cara Lee

'Inside' and 'Outside', these words were the theme of York University Photography Societyâ€™s exhibit â€“ aptly named Inside Outside â€“ which opened on 14 March. The doors opened at 6:30pm in the atrium of the Spring Lane building and when I arrived at around 7:00pm it was populated by about 20 people. I wasnâ€™t sure what to expect, having never been to an exhibit of this nature, but I was greeted by panels on either side of the room, each showcasing four or five photos taken by members of the society, with words written by the photographer accompanying the images. Beneath each photo was a code which could be used to vote on your favourite image of the event via a QR code that would direct you to a poll. Drinks and snacks were provided, I even spied a bottle of wine on the refreshments table, however I was nursing a minor headache so decided against such indulgence.

It was evident that it was the first exhibit in a long while, at least since the world was overturned by a certain virus two years ago; photos dated back as far as the now distant, and nostalgic - for me at least - first lockdown. They were taken on an array of formats, from iPhones to film and of varied subject matter. Next to a Tarkovsky-esque black and white portrait, of a girl in a mask looking longingly out the window (Andrea in Window Light by Kleo Palate) was a shot taken from the streets of Nanjing, China with the sun illuminating a skyscraper as if itâ€™s about to perform an all-important soliloquy on stage (Nanjing Tower by Youwei Fang.) The former was shot on film (with a Mamiya RB67 camera on hp5 film to be exact) which allows the image a certain texture that was absent in many of the digital photos. This texture gives the photo a timeless feel, yet the facemask on the subject anchors the image in contemporary society â€“ which Kleo pointed out in his caption of the photo.

Another stand out photo was Cascade by Yassen Khan; it showcased a broken crystal bowl basking in the afternoon light as it cascaded through an open door. Inside the bowl seemed to be a collection of rose petals which mirrored the burgundy coat in the background, these red tones worked alongside the warm light to create a cosy feel, Yassen lauded the Kodak 35mm film which facilitated such beautiful golden tones. Such tones, alongside the subject matter, gives the image a decidedly vintage feel, which is contradicted by the plainly modern car keys laying beside the bowl.

Beneath Cascade was Toxic Sea by Adam MacLean, the black and white image was of a lone figure standing on the borderline between sea and sand in Adamâ€™s coastal hometown, again shot on film. In the caption Adam described how the photo was taken on the day the government declared the coast unsafe for humans due to illegal sewage dumping, however after lobbying from Southern Water this dumping was decided to be legal. Without such a caption the image would act as a pensive piece, but after reading it the photo took on a new, more forlorn atmosphere. A similar effect occurred when viewing The Random Thoughts on 24 Feb by Yue Wang, the geopolitically enthused among us may recognise 24 February as the day Russia invaded Ukraine. The image features a man small in the frame standing by the edge of a river, with the trees ominously looming behind him, dark in the black and white film. In the caption, Yue remarked that the man looks tiny among the sky, trees, river, and field, so why should such powerless beings arrogantly start a war that would desecrate the authority of nature? These two photos worked to show how an effective caption can elevate the power of an image, from an abstract impression to an emotionally charged and specific message.

My attention then turned to a pair of photos presented as one piece â€“ Sublime by Molly Black. Before reading the caption, I was struck by the vivid skyscapes of the two images, one of the images portrayed the Minster at a low angle, behind it was a crisp nightâ€™s sky populated by clouds, with stars dotted throughout. The sky looked almost unnaturally stimulating, the type of grand airspace you would expect from a fantasy film, all that was missing was a giant alien planet looming amongst the clouds. Once reading the caption this skyscape became more understandable, Molly had replaced the sky with more dramatic photos of the sky taken previously, as soon as I read this my mind clicked, and the images took on a new, more experimental tone. These two photos were a particular favourite of my partner, who accompanied me for the evening.

It was hard to pick a favourite, and the QR codes on the corner of each panel taunted me, applying even more pressure to decide. Vienna in September by Jess Smith, of a plain wooden chair in front of a graffiti clad deep blue cargo container, Silhouette by Chen Manqing, depicting the Minster reflected in a puddle (shot on a simple iPhone 12Pro,) a photo of a child through the windows of Five Guys â€“ Curiosity by Maria Valenstain â€“ were among the shots that almost won my vote for favourite. My partnerâ€™s favourite was Reclaiming Pink by Millie Oâ€™Brien, a portrait for Hard Magazine of Loz Green, with a pink mullet and purple facial art. In the caption Loz outlined their feelings towards the colour pink: â€˜Having pink hair and embracing the colour in a way outside of the binary allows me to express both my femininity and masculinity without compromising my genderless identity.â€™ Monstera Mirror was an early favourite of mine, shot on digital by Celeste Bergne, depicting a green plant with light shining onto it through a stained-glass window. The green tones gave the image the thick atmosphere of a humid greenhouse.

Ultimately, it was Victoria Quarter Portrait by Matt Parkin that won the vote for my favourite; the simple image depicts a man smiling into the camera, however the colours elevate this to a truly unique piece. The caption explains how it was shot in a Leeds arcade, the bright yellows illuminate the background and cast their light onto the subject in an almost ethereal manner. What stood this image apart was its texture, stemming from the film it was shot on (Portra 400 3mm.) The photo was unmistakably captured on an analogue format, with the numerous scratches on the film to prove this; these imperfections gave the photo a more personal touch, and, alongside the colours, planted the image in some kind of kaleidoscopic dreamscape.

Of course, the photos Iâ€™ve discussed in this article merely scratch the surface of what Inside Outside had to offer, while often times the admittedly broad theme seemed to retreat into the background, and was more apparent on some than others, I wouldnâ€™t fault the exhibit for this. It is evident the society wanted to display their favourite photos from the past two years or so and forcing entries to have a more direct link to the theme could have limited this. Overall, it was a pleasant evening that got the artistic juices flowing, the atmosphere was friendly, and the atrium seemed to be populated by students and lecturers alike. Iâ€™ll be sure to attend the next exhibit the Photography Society holds and look forward to it.
